SEARCH
Package math.core

Class Notationer

java.lang.Object
math.core.Notationer
Direct Known Subclasses:
Digit
public class Notationer extends Object
Manages the format and convertion between differents numeric notations. Intended to be only used as a stakeholder manager for its static functions.

Example of use:



		public class MyClass extends Notationer{

			//Rest of the code implementing the Notationer static functions

		}
Since:
v0.0.1

  • Constructor Details

  • Method Details

    • validateAndNormalize

      protected static String[] validateAndNormalize(StringBuilder number)
      Recieves a number as a StringBuilder paramether, validates it to make sure it is infact a number and normalizes it to make readable in case it is not on a standard notation.

      Example of use:

      

			String[] parts = Notationer.validateAndNormalize(new StringBuilder(

				"1234.56"

			));
      The return values will be parts[0] = 1234 and parts[1] = 56
      Parameters:
      number - Number as a StringBuilder.
      Returns:
      String[] Returns a String array with the integer part and the decimal part of the number.
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if StringBuilder number is either null or empty.
      Since:
      0.0.1
      See Also:
      • expandScientificNotation(StringBuilder)
      • trimZeros(String)
      • cleanNonNumericCharacters(String)
      • splitIntoIntegerAndDecimalParts(String)

    • format

      protected static String format(String integerPart, String decimalPart, boolean useDecimalPointNotation)
      Recieves a number as two String paramethers, one representing the integer part and the other representing its decimal part and a boolean paramether that tells if the number uses decimal point notation. This paramether is true if it does.

      Example of use:

      

			String n = Notationer.format("1234", "56");
      The return values will be either n = 1,234.56 in case the boolean useDecimalPointNotation paramether if true or n = 1.234,56 in case is false.
      Parameters:
      integerPart - Integer Part of a number as a String.
      decimalPart - Decimal Part of a number as a String.
      useDecimalPointNotation - Tells if it uses or not decimal point notation as a boolean.
      Returns:
      String Returns a number as a String with the specified notation declared on the boolean useDecimalPointNotation paramether.
      Since:
      0.0.1
      See Also:
      • formatIntegerPart(StringBuilder, String, char)

    • expandScientificNotation

      protected static StringBuilder expandScientificNotation(StringBuilder scientificNumber)
      Recieves a number as a StringBuilder paramether, validates it to make sure it is infact in scientific notation, if so it will return the number expanded, if not it will return itself.

      Example of use:

      

			StringBuilder n = Notationer.expandScientificNotation(new StringBuilder(

				"1.23456E3"

			));
      The return values will be n = 1234.56
      Parameters:
      scientificNumber - Number in scientific notation as a StringBuilder.
      Returns:
      StringBuilder Returns a StringBuilder with the number expanded.
      Since:
      0.0.1

    • cleanNonNumericCharacters

      protected static StringBuilder cleanNonNumericCharacters(String number)
      Recieves a number as a String paramether, validates its back and front, and then removes every non numeric characters.

      Example of use:

      

			StringBuilder n = Notationer.cleanNonNumericCharacters("--.012++");
      The return values will be parts[0] = 0.0123
      Parameters:
      number - Number as a String.
      Returns:
      StringBuilder Returns a StringBuilder number that is a full readable.
      Since:
      0.0.1

    • splitIntoIntegerAndDecimalParts

      protected static String[] splitIntoIntegerAndDecimalParts(String number)
      Recieves a number as a String paramether, validates if it has a decimal part, if not it will fills it with empty to make sure it always return a 2 lenght String array.

      Example of use:

      

			String[] parts = Notationer.splitIntoIntegerAndDecimalParts("1234.56");
      The return values will be parts[0] = 1234 and parts[1] = 56
      Parameters:
      number - Number as a String.
      Returns:
      String[] Returns a String array with the integer and decimal part.
      Since:
      0.0.1

    • trimZeros

      protected static String trimZeros(String str)
      Recieves a number as a String paramether, validates if it has a decimal point to extend the regrex statement to not trim the zeros at the end if it is not a decimal number.

      Example of use:

      

			String n = Notationer.trimZeros("00000001234.56000000000");
      The return values will be n = 1234.56
      Parameters:
      str - Number as a String.
      Returns:
      String Returns a String with the zeros trimed.
      Since:
      0.0.1

    • formatIntegerPart

      protected static void formatIntegerPart(StringBuilder formatted, String integerPart, char separator)
      Recieves a empty StringBuilder recipient paramether, the integer part of a number as a String and char separator.

      Example of use:

      

			StringBuffer n = new StringBuilder();
			char separator = ',';

			Notationer.trimZeros(n, "1234", separator);
      The new n value will be 1,234
      Parameters:
      formatted - Empty recipient as a StringBuilder.
      integerPart - Integer part of a number as a integerPart.
      separator - Separator as a char.
      Since:
      0.0.1
